cs.man.ac.uk.sample

Class BaseEditor

  • java.lang.Object
    • cs.man.ac.uk.sample.BaseEditor
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IEditor
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ARFFEditor, CSVEditor

    public class BaseEditor
extends java.lang.Object
implements IEditor
    The class BaseEditor specifies the basic object, for a class hierarchy, used to edit and sample data files.
    Version:
    1.0, 05/30/14
    Author:
    Rob Lyon

        Description copied from interface: IEditor
        Methods that gathers information about the file to be sampled. Assumes that the class labels are the last piece of data in each row.
        Specified by:

        Returns:
        true if successfully pre-processed, else false.

      • shuffle

        public boolean shuffle()
        Description copied from interface: IEditor
        Shuffles the rows of data within a file, however caution should be be used with this method. Large files may take a long time to shuffle, and may use up a great deal of RAM - this method has to load a file into memory to perform the shuffle.
        Specified by:
        shuffle in interface IEditor
        Returns:
        true if shuffled successfully, else false.

      • createMetaDataBinary

        public boolean createMetaDataBinary()
        Description copied from interface: IEditor

        Creates meta data this data file. Meta data contain extra information about the data within the file useful for sampling. Such meta data is actually necessary for us to correctly sample especially when a specific class distribution is required. This method takes the file represented by this class, parses it, and produces two new files:

        1. Original File Name.positive.meta
        2. Original File Name.negative.meta

        The first contains those positive examples in the original file i.e. those with class = 1, the second the negative examples. The new files are almost identical to the original files in terms of structure, except that they have an additional feature. This feature is the row location of each instance in the original file. So for instance if we have an ARFF file as follows:

        % Title : Original Data Set. RELATION Original ATTRIBUTE a NUMERIC ATTRIBUTE b NUMERIC ATTRIBUTE c NUMERIC ATTRIBUTE class {0,1} DATA 13 , 10 , 2 , 1 24 , 12 , 2 , 0 61 , 21 , 3 , 1 18 , 12 , 2 , 0 26 , 11 , 2 , 1 Then the positive ARFF file would be: % Title : Positives. RELATION Original ATTRIBUTE index NUMERIC ATTRIBUTE a NUMERIC ATTRIBUTE b NUMERIC ATTRIBUTE c NUMERIC ATTRIBUTE class {0,1} DATA 1 , 13 , 10 , 2 , 1 3 , 61 , 21 , 3 , 1 5 , 26 , 11 , 2 , 1 And the negative: % Title : Negatives. RELATION Original ATTRIBUTE index NUMERIC ATTRIBUTE a NUMERIC ATTRIBUTE b NUMERIC ATTRIBUTE c NUMERIC ATTRIBUTE class {0,1} DATA 2 , 24 , 12 , 2 , 0 4 , 18 , 12 , 2 , 0 By separating the classes in this way, we can create new sampled data sets from these files. In particular as we have the indexes of the classes, we can, using random number generation, choose indexes to include in a new sample.
        Specified by:
        createMetaDataBinary in interface IEditor
        Returns:
        true if successful, else false.

      • getMetaData

        public java.util.TreeMap<java.lang.Integer,java.lang.Integer> getMetaData(java.lang.String labelledDataPath)
        Description copied from interface: IEditor
        Obtains meta information from the ARFF files created by the IEditor.createMetaDataBinary() method. This method reads the modified ARFF file at the specified path, and extracts the row index of the instance from the file. For instance, the following is an example of a modified ARFF file containing only positive instances: % Title : Positives. RELATION Original ATTRIBUTE index NUMERIC ATTRIBUTE a NUMERIC ATTRIBUTE b NUMERIC ATTRIBUTE c NUMERIC ATTRIBUTE class {0,1} DATA 1 , 13 , 10 , 2 , 1 3 , 61 , 21 , 3 , 1 5 , 26 , 11 , 2 , 1 This method will extract the row index (i.e. 1,3,5 above), and store it in a hash map based data structure. The information above is in the hash map as follows: -------------------- | KEY | VALUE | -------------------- | 1 | 1 | | 2 | 3 | | 3 | 5 | -------------------- The reason we do this is so that we can more easily sample the positive and negative examples. For instance, to sample a positive example above, all we need to do is choose a random number between 1-3 (the key value) to obtain the index of a positive instance in the original file. Thus when we read the original file to sample it, we take only those positive examples that have been chosen randomly from the hash map structure depicted above.
        Specified by:
        getMetaData in interface IEditor
        Parameters:
        labelledDataPath - the path to the file containing positives.
        Returns:
        a hash map containing the patterns.

      • writeARFFHeader

        public boolean writeARFFHeader(java.lang.String destination,
                               java.lang.String title,
                               java.lang.String rel,
                               java.lang.String description)
        Description copied from interface: IEditor

        Specified by:
        writeARFFHeader in interface IEditor
        Parameters:
        destination - the file to write the header information to.
        title - the title of the ARFF file.
        rel - the name for the relation in the file.

      • writeARFFHeader

        public boolean writeARFFHeader(java.lang.String destination,
                               java.lang.String title,
                               java.lang.String rel,
                               java.lang.String description,
                               int[] featureIndexes)
        Description copied from interface: IEditor
        Writes out the header for an ARFF file, containing the specified features. Note: you must explicitly include the index of the class labels to have them included in the output file.
        Specified by:
        writeARFFHeader in interface IEditor
        Parameters:
        destination - the file to write the header information to.
        title - the title of the ARFF file.
        rel - the name for the relation in the file.
        description - a description of the relation.
        featureIndexes - the features to include.
        Returns:
        true if completed successfully, else false.

      • label

        public boolean label(int labelled,
                     int unlabelled,
                     int INSTANCES_TO_LABEL,
                     int INSTANCES_TO_NOT_LABEL,
                     double labelling)
        Description copied from interface: IEditor
        Methods which decides if an instance should be labelled or not.
        Specified by:
        label in interface IEditor
        Parameters:
        labelled - the number of instances currently labelled.
        unlabelled - the number of instances currently unlabeled.
        INSTANCES_TO_LABEL - the total number of instances that must be labelled.
        INSTANCES_TO_NOT_LABEL - the total number of instances that must remain unlabelled.
        labelling - the labeling ratio.
        Returns:
        true if the current instance should be labelled, else false.

      • sampleToCSV

        public boolean sampleToCSV(java.lang.String trainPath,
                           java.lang.String testPath,
                           int negTrainSamples,
                           int posTrainSamples,
                           double trainingSetBalance,
                           double testSetBalance,
                           double labelling)
        Description copied from interface: IEditor
        Samples a file producing an ARFF output.
        Specified by:
        sampleToCSV in interface IEditor
        Parameters:
        trainPath - the path to the training set file to create.
        testPath - the path to the test set file to create.
        negTrainSamples - the number of negative samples to include in the training set.
        posTrainSamples - the number of positive samples to include in the training set.
        trainingSetBalance - the class balance desired in the training set.
        testSetBalance - the class balance desired in the test set.
        labelling - the ratio of labelled data to aim for.
        Returns:
        true if sampled successfully, else false.
